bookDescription: The last humans in the solar system battle for survival—and encounter an alien AI—in this action-packed military science-fiction thriller. In the aftermath of a bioengineered plague that wiped out all life on Earth, Jupiter’s Europa colony has become the last bastion of human civilization, and it’s Lt. Ryan Braeder’s job to keep what remains of his species alive. With food and supplies dwindling, he has no choice but to take his last ships on a perilous journey to a dead colony on Ceres in a desperate bid to find provisions and replacement parts.What Braeder didn’t expect to find on the asteroid, among the barren regolith and deserted buildings, was a mutated virus and a rogue group of Russian scientists. Now, the more threads he pulls, the more he unravels a web of conspiracies, horrifying medical experiments, and a hidden threat that would see his crew marooned on the asteroid.Meanwhile, back on Europa, Braeder’s second-in-command, Rani Singh, stumbles across an alien artifact buried in the ice sheets. An extraterrestrial intelligence lurks inside, and with the colony’s power failing, Singh frantically searches for a way to communicate with the otherworldly object. However, the artifact seems to have an agenda of its own, and it’s impossible to know if it’s intentions are friendly . . . or deadly.Praise for Extinction“An interstellar yarn wrought with suspense and indelible characters.” —Kirkus Reviews“Leviathan Wakes meets Battlestar Galactica in this high-stakes story of survival on the moon of Jupiter. Heart-pounding and thrilling, Extinction follows an unlikely leader as he races to save humanity against impossible odds.” —Claire Barner, author of Moonrising“This insightful glimpse into our possible future is a must read.” —Sue Nelson Buckley, author of The Trouble with Jake and Hiding in Plain Sight“Packed with intense action, layered characters, and thought-provoking dilemmas . . . This is a story that lingers, making you ponder the fragile line between extinction and survival.” —Literary Titan

bookDescription:
Deep within Syndicate World space, the Alliance fleet continues its dangerous journey home under the command of Captain John “Black Jack” Geary—revived after a century spent in suspended animation. Geary’s victories over the enemy have earned him both the respect—and the envy—of his fellow officers…
“Black Jack” Geary has made many risky decisions as commander, but ordering the Alliance fleet back to the Lakota Star System where it had nearly been destroyed by the Syndics has his officers questioning his sanity. It’s a desperate gamble that may buy Geary just enough time to prepare for the Syndics’ inevitable return—and give the fleet a fighting chance of survival.
But even as he struggles to stay one step ahead of the enemy, Geary must face conspirators within his own fleet—an unknown number of officers who want a change of command. And Geary knows that his fleet must stand together or the Syndic forces will tear them apart…

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Valiant (2008) is the fourth naval SF novel in The Lost Fleet series, following Courageous.  The initial work in this sequence is Dauntless.In the previous volume, the fleet entered the Lakota system with eight Syndic capital ships following them.  A small flotilla of Syndic ships was guarding the hypernet gate.  A larger force exited from the T'negu jump.  Then an even larger Syndic force came through the hypernet gate.Fleet politics was still contentious.  Media joined Casia in criticizing the fleet commander.  Later, Renown lost propulsion and Media took the Paladin to her rescue.  Both ships were destroyed by the Syndics.Geary decided to leave the system.  Three battleships stayed behind as a rear guard.  Then the lost fleet jumped back to Ixion.  On the way, Iger told him that the Syndic fleet from the hypernet had not intended to arrive at the Lakota system.In this novel, Jack Geary is the designated acting commander of the fleet survivors.  He is the most senior captain within the Alliance due to his century long stasis is an escape pod.  Unfortunately, he is also trapped within his own legend.Tanya Desjani is an Alliance Captain, commanding the battlecruiser Dauntless.  She is Geary's Flag Captain.  She works well with Geary.Victoria Rione is the Co-president of the Callas Republic and a member of the Alliance Senate.  She is the only civilian within the fleet.  She had been Geary's lover for a few weeks.Casia is an Alliance Captain, commanding the battleship Conqueror.  His ship is in the Third Battleship Division, formerly commanded by Numos.Midea is an Alliance Captain, commanding the battleship Paladin.  She had served as executive officer of the Orion under Numos before being promoted.Iger is an Alliance Lieutenant in charge of intelligence gathering in the Dauntless.  He seems very competent and his personnel have provided some excellent information.  Naturally, his intelligence usually comes well after fleet operations.Carabali is an Alliance Colonel.  She is the senior officer among the remaining Marines of the fleet.In this story, the fleet is returning to the Lakota system.  The crews are enthusiastic about the opportunity to recover their lost comrades and to attack the Syndics again.  Rione is puzzled by the crew reaction and fearful of their chances.  Geary tries to explain his reasoning and the crew reaction, but she doesn't have a clue.When the fleet exits the jump point, both Geary and Rione are on the bridge.  The jump point is still mined, but the fleet avoids the field.  Most of the Syndic ships are damaged and the hypernet gate is not guarded.  They have definitely surprised the Syndics.Desjani wants to try for the hypernet gate, but Geary is not so eager.  He hasn't yet told her about the aliens controlling destinations in the hypernet.  He reminds her of the things that they need to do before the pursuing fleet catches up with them.Their first action is aimed at the shipyards and other facilities in the system.  Along the way, they will distribute recently manufactured expendables from the auxiliaries.  Geary and Desjani divvy up planning the maneuvers.An Alliance battleship is located within a large collection of damaged Syndic ships.  Sensor readings indicate that the Syndics have patched some damaged compartments.  Geary believes that the Audacious is being used as a prison for captured Alliance personnel.Geary is concerned about the Syndics blowing the power core of the battleship.  He broadcasts a threat to destroy every Syndic ship, shuttle, and escape pod in the system if the Alliance prisoners are killed.  Then the fleet heads toward the cluster of damaged ships to liberate the POWs as well as much needed materiel.Geary orders his ships to inflict maximum damage to the Syndic naval units and facilities, but to use hell-lances as much as possible to preserve existing expendables.  He also warns them about accidentally inducing a core overload on the Audacious.The Syndic guard force breaks up as it notices the Alliance fleet, with some heading toward the hypernet gate.  Geary thinks that they will guard the gate and destroy it if necessary.  But such destruction could result in the release of energy corresponding to a nova.Two Syndic battleships turn toward the Alliance fleet.  Geary wonders what these battleships are doing.  Desjani points out that they are defending the system even if the effort is hopeless.A damaged Syndic heavy cruiser is being towed away from the jump point.  The crews abandon ship in escape pods.  Geary has his ships pick up several pods for prisoner interrogation.Casia calls Geary with a complaint about the lack of oversight on the Marines raiding the Audacious.  Geary points out that he is supervising Carabali and she is supervising the Marine teams.  Casia counters that the Marines are not being directly supervised by the ship commanders.Geary discusses the issue with Desjani and learns that such practices are common within the Alliance Navy.  Geary wonders at the degree of micromanagement.  Then he firmly quashes Casia's complaints.  Geary also calls Carabali and assures her that such oversight will not be the norm within his fleet.The fleet takes out more damaged Syndics ships.  Then they attack the two incoming battleships.  The Marines reach the Audacious and take off the POWs.  Shortly thereafter, the Syndic pursuit fleet exits from the jump point.This tale has the Alliance fleet again maneuvering against a much larger fleet.  Geary has his crews prepare a surprise for the Syndics.  He again uses the fleet auxiliaries as bait.The lost fleet enters the jump point for Anahalt.  The next installment in this sequence is Relentless.Highly recommended for Campbell fans and for anyone else who enjoys tales of naval combat, service intrigue, and competent commanders.  Read and enjoy!-Arthur W. Jordin
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2011

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Book number four of a six book military science fiction series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Book number four of a six book military science fiction series.  Plus several sequel series consisting of fourteen books total.  I read the well printed and well bound MMPB published by Ace in 2008 that I bought on Amazon.  I have purchased the two sequel books in this series and plan to read them soon.I did not know John G. Hemry was the real name for Jack Campbell as I purchased the Stark series quite a while back and enjoyed it also.The Alliance sent a war fleet into the Syndic home star system via the new FTL network to defeat the Syndics once and for all.  However, the Syndics knew that they were coming and destroyed many of the Alliance space warships.  Now the Alliance warships need to leave or be destroyed one by one.The Alliance admiral left Captain John “Black Jack” Geary in charge of the Alliance fleet before he and his staff were murdered by the Syndics in the negotiations.  Captain John “Black Jack” Geary was found by the Alliance fleet on their way to Syndic space, in stasis in an old emergency pod.  A hundred year old emergency pod.  Captain John “Black Jack” Geary may be a hundred years out of date but some things like tactics of war spaceship fleets never go away.Captain Geary is leading his fleet of warships and supply ships through old wormholes, trying to anticipate Syndic attacks and gather raw materials and feed his crews.  After they exit the wormhole from the Lakota star system, he turns the fleet around and goes back.  What they find surprises them greatly.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: We're Going Back  Where ? Not Me !!
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Earth is at war with the Syndic. Who are human just like you and me but take an entirely different perspective on what is right and wrong. What's right is anything that financially or politically benefits them. What's wrong is everything else.What started this war that has been going on for 100 years ? No one seems to remember but the important thing is to destroy the other guy. And that's the premise for the entire series of 6 books, recently expanded to 7 although on a different story arc with the same characters in this series.Things get really sideways in this volume as Admiral Geary's decision to take the fleet back to the scene of their worst defeat, the Lukota system, has many Captains questioning what the Admiral is up to. Disobedience and contrary actions during battle are creating untenable conditions for Admiral Geary.But Admiral Geary knows it's the right decision, or is it ? It will certainly surprise the Syndic Fleet which is now spread throughout Syndic space trying to catch the Earth fleet .Admiral Geary proceeds with his plan to the advantage of Earth's fleetThis a great military science fiction series with well developed characters and space battle strategies
Good book. Lots of action and well thought out characters. Recommend the series and the author, links military navy well.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 17, 2024

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Du point science-fiction militaire stricto sensu ce tome fait bien  l'affaire .Mais «  le reste « ,  est vraiment très moyen , pour ce qui est de la mise en oeuvre de l'intrigue et du contexte général  .La caractérisation  vraiment n'est pas au top ,  et à force cela fini par rejaillir sur le personnage principal , qui s'époumone un peu dans un désert de crédibilité , du point de vue de la densité du casting.Geary , alias Black Jack , aimerait bien faire relâche au port , mais le voilà encore obligé de combattre dans des circonstances difficiles et avec une flotte raplapla ..L'intrigue est finalement assez mince . Le « casting «  est suffisamment fonctionnel  néanmoins et de ce fait malgré tout  , ce tome est une pièce sympa de science-fiction militaire .Le bouquin est donc  un peu lobotomisé , mais ça passe à mon humble avis  .En toute franchise ,  je pense que l'auteur devrait écrire en duo avec une plume plus littéraire ,  un minimum en tout cas et plus que lui certainement  .L'auteur n'est pas intégralement  et lourdement Semper Fi et de ce point  sa prose n'est pas désagréable et elle est  digeste  .Sa compétence militaire qui suinte littéralement de toute ces pages , n'est pas désagréable non plus  . De ce point vue rien à dire d'ailleurs et la passerelle est incontestablement la passerelle d'un navire de combat crédible comme celle d'un navire amiral .Dommage que ce ne soit pas un sans-faute et il ne l'est pas et de loin , malheureusement .

bookDescription: The guild is under attack, and Van is right in the middle of it all.When Master Yewlo is abducted by unknown forces, the Peacemakers are thrown into chaos as the rescue mission begins. Finding Yewlo will be hard, but the search reveals secrets the guild might not survive—secrets about a system so corrupt, it will take Van and his team’s best efforts to untangle the truth.And they might not like what they find.On the grimy station known as Halcyon, Van will track and confront thieves who deal in stolen lives, all in order to save a Master who might not have the guild’s best interest at heart. With Sorcerers and Cloaks and every other kind of criminal, Van, Torina, Perry and Icky learn that friends come in all shapes and sizes—and so do enemies.From the depths of space to Iowa, join Van as he fights to save his guild, free stolen lives, and discover that money makes the universe go around—money and lies, that is.And Van will find the truth, no matter what the cost.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Witty, fun, great characters and story line
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I loved this audible book.  The characters are interesting; the world is a bit different, which makes it interesting.  The writing style and dialogue are witty without being slapstick.  I love the play on words and the humor from deliberate slight misinterpretation that the characters play off each other.  Its a great way to write personalities to show the character.  The plot is imaginative, and the protagonist is basically a good guy who is pragmatically ruthless when necessary.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 28, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Engaging plot and characters, with loose threads that are forgiveable
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The storyline of finding a spaceship in grandpa's barn, along with a couple of non-rogue super-intelligent AI's who just happen to show you the road to becoming a galactic knight-errant, is less than believable. The technical stuff is, let's just say, less than believable. So why should you read this story? The answer is a good and fast-paced storyline. Adolescent dialogue aside, the story is FUN to read, and the characters are by and large fun to follow on their journey. Also, the authors seem to have had fun writing this, which adds to the reading pleasure. Nothing is worse than abored writer just having to push out a sequel before a deadline. Warning - you need to start with book 1 and go from there, and you might end up spending more time and money on this than you intend.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I can’t believe I waited until finishing the third book to write a review. In all candor, it’s because as soon as I’m done I want to read the next one. I had the first book for quite some time before even started reading it. I would’ve thought it was going to be a “campy” lope of a story about humans experiencing space. There’s nothing wrong with campy I like that and it is alright,  but the sophistication and enduring qualities of the characters, are superb. (it is not a story about humans, it’s a story about space and humans are just apart, not even the central part ). The science fiction ideas and different alien cultures are so much fun with common human themes of concern. Like money, needing to have a form of barter to function. but I particularly enjoy is the extremely witty repertoire between the characters which include endearing and lovable, if not deadly AI characters. The loving disrespect in comments is qoute worthy. I read a lot of sci-fi, lots of great writers, I think a von Hefner and his great stories, Craig alanson and his comedic dialogue between characters, and these authors definitely match if not exceed it. My most exciting thing is I have 12 more books to read then on to other storylines. Thank you! (One saying which I’m sure is not original, very military which I greatly enjoyed was, "The only thing on the battlefield that travels faster than a bullet is a rumor.")

bookDescription: Prepare yourself for an adrenaline-pumping journey in the latest installment of the Able Bodied Soldier series!Titus Briggs leads humanity's bravest warriors as they embark on a massive joint operation against the formidable Thephari stronghold. This unprecedented mission brings together multiple MOCOM units and SDF forces in a desperate bid to permanently end the threat of a second invasion. The stakes have never been higher, and the action never more intense.From the very first page, you'll be thrust into a world of relentless combat and high-stakes missions. Follow Titus and his team as they wipe out the remnants of a Moonie cult, test the limits of wormhole travel, and launch a daring raid on the Thephari homeworld. The tension escalates as Titus faces a critical decision about his future, choosing whether to fight alongside his comrades despite a debilitating injury.Witness the full-scale invasion of the enemy wormhole hub, a pivotal moment that could change the course of the war. With the fate of Earth and its colonies hanging in the balance, every decision counts, and every battle is a fight for survival.Able Bodied Soldier 3 is a must-read for fans of military science fiction. Experience the thrill of epic battles, the camaraderie of soldiers, and the resilience of the human spirit. Don't miss out on this electrifying adventure—grab your copy today and join the fight!

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Edgar Rice Boroughs published the first version of “Beyond the Farthest Star” in 1942 in Blue Book Magazine.  By June of 1975 it was available in paperback.  It was the first book I stayed up all night to read.  I was 12.Robert Hienlien  published “Starship Troopers” in 1959.  Because of his politics, when Hollywood got finished with his novel, Hienlien rolled in his grave.These two gave birth to military sci-fi.  Hienlien even gave us powered armor in his version.It is great to see that authors like Channey and Anspatch are working hard to keep the genre alive, interesting, and read.Great job, guys.

bookDescription: Major Titus "Wheels" Briggs is fighting the war he vowed to finish. Briggs now commands the elite Joint Strike Force, Crimson Talon against the relentless Thephari. bookDescription: The Universe is a bloody mess. Time to put on your cleaning gloves.During a routine arrest, Van discovers a stolen spacecraft, its importance far greater than it first appears. Fast, sleek, and beautiful, the ship is a cultural relic from Linulla’s people, and returning their property will set off a chain of events that reveals a new adversary.Rising in the ranks, Van’s confrontation with a pirate leader isn’t just a case of theft, but something far more sinister.And Van’s going to take this case personally.He and his crew will chase the Salt Thieves and their leader in a game that can only have one winner.Will Van rise to the challenge? Can Icky control her temper? Will Perry make Icky wear pants?The answer is more complicated than it seems.And far more dangerous, for that matter, than anything Van has ever done before. But he’s got a new edge on the Moonsword, a new rank, and a new crew as he takes his Dragon to the stars with one thing in mind...Justice.The #1 bestselling science fiction series of the year returns for its sixth entry with Distant Horizons. If you're a fan of classic adventure stories, relatable humor, and a hero that refuses to quit, you'll love the Backyard Starship series.

bookDescription: Brad Mendoza is an idiot. He knows it, and so does everyone else in the star nation of Prometheus. A promising naval career down the drain just because he accidentally killed 504 civilians. So, it's time for him to give up and accept a dead-end command on Persephone, the worst starship in the fleet. Until he meets the beautiful and cunning Jessica Lin, his new executive officer, who harbors a terrible secret of her own. Now, with an enemy warship four times their size bearing down on them, Brad's in a race to save Jessica and his stupid ship.But Brad Mendoza is an idiot. We'll just have to hope that he's the lucky kind.An exciting military sci-fi adventure and space crime thriller with plenty of twists and turns and snarky humor. Order today!This book was first published on Kindle Vella as The Worst Ship in the Fleet, episodes 1-18.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Fast paced action in space seen through a wry perspective.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: A quick read, reminding me of The Murderbot Diaries (and this book only has a score more pages to go). The humour is with us from the start, seen through the self-deprecating MC, and the world building comes natural through dialogue and action (no info dumps). The book feels like the first one in a series, limning the cast who I hope we’ll meet further down the page. I feel it deals with trauma in a somewhat cursory way, solving it logically, but not emotionally. And mind you, if you like to think out the solutions in the story (like in a murder mystery), this book isn’t about that. The solutions they come up with are part of the world building so you can’t know beforehand (but the solutions are plausible and rhymes with our world, so they are easy to buy, except for one time when it felt out of character, but that might explained when I read further).That said, it’s well worth spending your time with if you want fast paced action seen through a wry perspective.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is the first book I've read by Skyler Ramirez and I'm glad I found his work.  This first book was a refreshing read, light and funny and a fun adventure.  My only con first: it's short.  Weighing in at 137 pages, the first book is over quickly after the characters and world are established.  When I realized I was a third of the way through the book and I was still getting up to speed with the beginning of the main plot, I almost put it down.  But then I saw it was a series.  And that leads into the pros: It's an interesting world with interesting characters.  Brad Mendoza is a lovable self-destructive buffoon, with a past he hasn’t come to terms with.  He’s funny and self-depreciating, and the running narrative from his jaded perspective keeps the story moving.  Jessica Lin comes off as a two dimensional Miss Perfect but I think the coming books will flesh out her character more.  She’s got a past too, that will need to come to light.  There’s just the right amount of world-building for a book this length and I can’t wait to see what the rest of the series looks like.  And I’m hoping the antagonist from the first book ends up being the villain of the series.  We’ll see.  I highly recommend this if you’re looking for a light, clean, funny space adventure.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 17, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: At first I thought the main character was awful, didn't get a good feel for him. He grew on me though and I got to enjoy his self deprecating personality. The story kept me turning the pages and I'm actually looking forward to continuing the series.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Fun quick space opera read. Light humorous reading with basic characterization with implications of going deeper in future books. I went ahead and ordered the rest of series that has been written so far and published in paperback.  I have since read several more of the series books. productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 14, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Where’s the Sixth Star for Awesomeness!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I happened upon this book somewhat by accident.  As a new author in the genre I made it a point to familiarize myself with other books like what I was writing. It checked the boxes of social proof with a high number of reviews and the blurb was intriguing. What I didn’t expect was a wildly entertaining ride through the galaxy with Brad and Jessica, all orchestrated by Maestro Ramirez!The writing is great, the action is fast paced, but best of all, the humanity of the characters is what really shines through!  Skyler Ramirez’s style is not what one typically expects in many genres nowadays: he proves that an author can write without any gratuitous language and violence, but yet keeps it real. It’s refreshing, actually.I’m writing this review as I read through the 8th of this series since I got so into them I forgot to pay it forward to highly endorse this series!  It’s not just this series too, so read everything else Skyler has written.  Don’t be like Brad and go READ!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 16, 2025

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Hooks you in for a fast-paced adventure
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I wasn't sure about this book at first, just from the blurb and details on Amazon, I tend to avoid the smaller books and go for longer ones that have some world building. But I gave this a chance, and I was immediately hooked, very short read, there's enough depth to the characters to get a sense on things and then it takes you on a whirlwind of an adventure. The story keeps building in the next book, and the one after (just starting the 4th now).I've not been able to put them down, enjoying the story, the flow, and the characters. Very entertaining reads that aren't over the top so it ends up being relaxing to read. Would highly recommend!

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I've been an avid reader my entire adult life, since the 70s. In this day of self-publishing, there's a lot of bad writing out there now that in the past never would have made it to the press. A reader often has to wade through a lot of badly written slop before finding someone who can actually write well. So I'm very happy to have recently discovered Mr. Ramirez. He knows how to write and he delivers on the promise of his titles. It's light-hearted escapism, and very, very funny. And his writing skill is excellent, a pleasure to read. I will be reading the rest of the series.

I'm not overly enthusiastic about broken heroes and started the book a little reluctantly. What can I say. I read it in one go and was annoyed when someone tried to interrupt me. Yes, it is that entertaining and well written. If you are into space opera, have a go and enjoy yourself.I will definitely read the next book in the series. Like, right now.
Not entirely sure why I picked up this book. Upto 59% it’s pure nonsense after which I skipped and went to rating the book.
This is a great read different from any sc fi I have read I loved the humor in this book make sure you read it .

bookDescription: With his new rank, secrets begin to unfold for Van as war and politics become one and the same. The Fafnir is no longer a mere ship—it’s a force to be reckoned with, but it isn’t complete.One possible answer lies in deep space, in a secret facility funded by an array of allies. But this laboratory creates something far more deadly than a virus or a weapon.It produces ships.Null Stellarium is more than a shipyard. It’s a proving ground, steeped with science and engineering designed to push warships faster than ever before, and armed to confront the growing menace of a universe where everything is influenced by a hidden evil.As Van and his crew grow into their new roles, Perry unlocks a memory that reaches into the very beginning of the Tudor family’s service, nearly a century earlier.But sometimes, the truth is hidden for a reason, and Van must decide—How much does he really want to know? And how far can he take his ship, knowing there’s a price on his head?

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: New characters, new challenges,  and an ongoing mystery going back two generations. It's an action filled ride that never seems to end

I've had backyard starship book one as a sample downloaded for a while, but I kept ignoring it as it was made by two authors and having so many in the series. Came round to it after struggling to find something to read, read the first sample, immediately bought the book half way through, then kept buying them and reading the series back to back, and wow I was wrong to think that two authors would be a problem, this is an amazing book series. The only downside is the 14th book isn't yet available and the last one ended in the middle of things (unlike the others which round things off a bit for the current story, but still leave you wanting more).For the most part the books feel very episodic, building up the world and overarching story over each book like a good TV series. There's some unexpected turns, fun times, sad times, big space battles, small space battles, robots, aliens, humans, love interests, its all there and for the most part, well written.Now to find something that can fill the gap before June rolls around the new book drops, life will be a struggle.

bookDescription:
Admiral John "Black Jack" Geary may have saved the Alliance only to destroy it in this thrilling and eagerly awaited continuation of the New York Times best-selling series.
Geary believed in the Alliance. Even when he uncovered overwhelming evidence that the highest echelons of the government and fleet command were involved in secret programs and prison camps, he believed it was worth saving. He believed his duty was to see that justice was served even though some factions feared that revealing the truth would cause the Alliance to crumble.
But after narrowly surviving two assassination attempts when he brings evidence of the misdeeds to the capital star system, Geary realizes that some have decided the easiest way to make the Alliance's problems go away is to get rid of him. He finds himself ordered to undertake a perilous new mission outside of the reaches of human-occupied space while the Senate clashes over the evidence.
Geary's warships must escort a diplomatic and scientific mission across the dangerous, disintegrating remnants of the Syndicate Worlds empire. But even if he can make it to Midway Star System, the gateway to alien-controlled space, Geary will face former Syndicate officials who have rebelled and regard the Alliance with deep suspicion. And that will be the easy part....

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I've been a fan of the series for a long time, and this book doesn't disappoint. If you liked the characters and the stories from the earlier books in the series, you're going to like this one. Same great main character, same group of friends and colleagues around him. And at least one great moment that I've been waiting for for a long time.Those complaining about the price don't understand publishing. Giving the book a bad review because of the price only punishes the author, who didn't set the price, it's not going to affect publishing's pricing model.  And the last time a book in the series came out, I paid hardcover price of over $25. This book cost less.I'm looking forward to the rest of the books in this new series. Thank you, Jack Campbell, for writing more.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I’m only going to talk about Jack Campbell’s new story Boundless in the most general terms. Boundless is a fast-moving page-turner in which Campbell picks up as many of the threads of the previous and original series (plural) as I can remember. He uses those threads to weave together a taut thriller that will propel readers to search for the pattern that will emerge in this new Outlands series.Is it essential to have read all of previous books? No, you can enjoy this thriller without having read those, but Campbell seems to get better with each story and his characters are worthy of your time.I can’t wait to see what happens next.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 10, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is a great series of books, and is currently on the 'central shelf' for quick access to reread. Plenty of intrigue and action and a compelling story that, for me, has yet to grow stale.My one and only critique for Mr. Campbell - if he is reading this - is to write from more than one character's perspective. The entire series is strictly from the main character's point of view, thankfully still in the 'omni' rather than 'singular.' But I would love to have scenes from Desjani's perspective, or from Duellos or Carabali. I feel it would make for a far more rounded story, and certainly make the loss of some characters a lot more impactful.Well worth a read. And then anther. And then another, and another....

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Ever a good read, this author. This took me back to my teenage years, reading E E Smith, Edgar Rice Burroughs, Heinlein and A E Van Vogt to name but a few. productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Por un lado...-La relacion Desjani &Geary sigue igual de irritante a pedazos, es como leer un manga Tsundere de repente (igual y hay gente que le gustan este tipo de relaciones)-Siguen llorando las perdidas lo que se vuelve de repente molesto ya que se utiliza el trauma (de las diferentes perdidas) para justificar comportamientos en todo momento y esto se puede ver muy claro con las aluciones a Cresida. En este sentido la inclusion de un personaje nuevo que tiene claro eso, y actua con ese enojo sin justificarlo ni temerlo es refrescante y agradable.-Entiendo que se quiere hacer enfasis en lo que sufren y afecta quienes van en la guerra pero hay un punto en el que se vuelven insoportables por no trabajarlo (en este sentido las decisiones de la familia Duellos me parecen tambien muy refrescantes)Por otro lado...-La trama sigue avanzando y creo que trae respuestas mas rapido-Me gusta que despues de tanto tiempo Geary sea mas decido y tome acciones para cambiar la situacion de los militares y la alianza en general (quiero suponer que esto flrma parte de la evolucion del personaje)-Hay batallas espaciales y tambien intrigas de otro estilo, lo que me gusto muchoEn resumen: Sigue siendo lo mismo con los mismo (situacion que vemos desde el segundo libro pero seguimos aqui) y la trama avanza. Me gusta

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Worthy sequel to The Lost Fleet Saga
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: TL;DR : An excellent book of naval sci-fi, which uses it's rythm perfectly.A long love of mine, I read most of this serie (all of the Lost Fleet Saga) in french. Unable to withstand the wait for the translation, I got this copy.I was pleasantly surprised to see that it's easy to read, and the story told is as good as the others. If you loved the others books in this universe, it's a must have. The author succeeded in entertwining everything from his different series in this universe (Lost Stars, Genesis of the Fleet) in a way that should not lose any reader that would take up the book without reading them.Only little downside, I've spotted some editing error on some of the chapter introductions, but nothing too serious.I'll wait for the next book - until summer 2022 apparently. To lessen the weight, I just started a read over of the entire serie.
La lettura è piacevole e assorbente come peraltro per tutta la serie della lost fleet dello stesso autore, purchè ovviamente si consideri interessante la fantascienza classica e di tipo militare.

As with all Lost Fleet books, the first one of this new series called Outlands delivers great quality of sci-fi. It definitively scratched that itch to see Admiral Geary back in action, it had ships, political intrigue, great characters and I'm left with a satisfied feeling and a few more questions about the future ;)

bookDescription:
Admiral John “Black Jack” Geary fears the greatest threat to humanity may be itself in this gripping continuation of the New York Times bestselling series.
As far from explored space as any human has ever been, Geary and the Alliance fleet are on their own, protecting a diplomatic mission in territory belonging to an alien species with still-unknown motives.
His already complex and dangerous mission is further imperiled by deadly challenges from other human factions seeking to harm or exploit the aliens. When another alien species whose technology is far more advanced than humanity’s arrives, the stakes are raised to the highest possible level.
Only the most serious danger comes from an unexpected source.
When presented with orders to carry out actions he believes not only are mistaken but would be contrary to the ideals of the Alliance, Geary has to finally decide whether he must invoke the power that his long-revered name holds, all the while knowing that this might endanger his entire fleet, tear apart the Alliance, and destroy everything he has fought for.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: An extraordinary end to an extraordinary trilogy
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This was a masterpiece of a military space opera. As I have told you before, I am one not much for military novels, but this one was excellently written and was about the characters, rather than the action, although there is plenty of action as well. The main characters John "Black Jack" Geary and his ships' Captain wife, Tanya Desjani are two very formidable characters in a wildly fluctuating diplomatic scene. To top it off, there are powers who want to see the famous captain and the Head diplomat fail in their trying to open diplomatic relations with the "Dancers", a species that had helped them in prior conflicts and doing everything they can to sabotage their efforts. I most highly recommend this trilogy and especially this book.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Book Three in the Lost Fleet: Outlands series, so that would make this number fourteen in the entire Lost Fleet shebang.At the end of the previous book, Admiral Geary was sent to Dancer space to strengthen diplomatic relations with those enigmatic aliens.  He also encounters one of the Toan and a representative from a new species, the Wooareek. Unfortunately, several really big problems arise while he's trying to carry out his orders. The biggest difficulties come from humanity rather than the aliens.I really enjoyed reading this.  I love the characters!  (Ensign Duck still needs a bigger role, though.) The story unfolded at a very slow pace for a while, and then BAM! it was one complication after another.  The long scene with the arrival of the insane Alliance CEO- not a Syndic CEO- was excellent.The ending is sufficiently open-ended to allow for a sequel. I sincerely hope that he doesn't dawdle in writing another!  I'll definitely buy that sucker.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: One of the best sci-fiction books written so far
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Why I liked the serie? Because all of them are fascinating, full of interesting and strong characters, full of emotion (sadness and happiness), excitement and non-stop action. No need for long explanations, just get the books and read.PS: I have the full set. Also waiting for the 5th and6th books ofThe Lost Stars (President Iceni, Gnr Drakon, Kommodors Marphissa & Bradamont) and of course the books of the OUTLANDS after Resolute. Thanks to Jack Campbell. I hope there will be a Galaxy Map showing all allien star systems around Alliance, in the coming books.

Latest book in the 'Lost Fleet' series of military science fiction novels. This has been going for a while. This is the third series of books to feature the main characters from it. It's also had a spin off trilogy. And a prequel trilogy. So it's not a good jumping on point.New readers go to 'The Lost Fleet: Dauntless'. Regular ones, read on.This one runs for four hundred and forty six pages. It's divided into eighteen chapters. There's the usual list of the make up of the fleet at the start.This seems to bring the current run 'The Lost Fleet: Outlands' to a close. More on that in a moment.Anyway, picking up from the end of the last book, Geary has to contend with trying to understand the aliens called the Dancers more. With other alien species also making contact. And with new arrivals from human space. One such brings orders. That present a big problem. And a very tricky choice...You know what you're going to get with these books by now. And this provides exactly that. It doesn't disappoint, either. It does take about sixty pages to really get going. But then it never looks back. We do get all the usual moral dilemmas that Jack has re his legend. But that never gets boring. Which is good that the writing makes to make it fresh all the time.It does for the bulk of things end up being more of a story of alien human contact than space battles. But this is still really good reading. Because as ever it manages to make the aliens so completely alien, that the two sides trying to understand each other is riveting stuff.It does some solid characterisation with the scientists who are with the fleet trying to understand all this. One in particular becomes a very three dimensional creation indeed.Where this really clicks though is in the final quarter. Because the dilemmas that all the characters from the Fleet, and not just Jack, face in this section make for a fabulous page turner. I really couldn't put this down for a moment. It does offer moral food for thought to readers as well, re what you would do in the same situation. Books that make you think for yourself like that are always worth it.Then you see there's been clever plotting all along, as the way one main situation works itself out is really great and makes so much sense when you think about it.Although this does work perfectly as an end to the Outlands trilogy, there are still loose ends dangling when this finishes. So hopefully more is to come.A superb read, and one of the best in this series. Hoping it's not the end.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on August 12, 2023

bookDescription: The launch of a new science fiction adventure series--by the New York Times-best selling author of the Safehold series and the Honor Harrington series  The Galactic Hegemony has been around a long time, and it likes stability--the kind of stability that member species like the aggressive, carnivorous Shongairi tend to disturb. So when the Hegemony Survey Force encountered a world whose so-called "sentients"--"humans," they called themselves--were almost as bad as the Shongairi themselves, it seemed reasonable to use the Shongairi to neutralize them before they could become a second threat to galactic peace. And if the Shongairi took a few knocks in the process, all the better.Now, Earth is conquered. The Shongairi have arrived in force, and humanity's cities lie in radioactive ruins. In mere minutes, more than half the human race has died.Master Sergeant Stephen Buchevsky, who thought he was being rotated home from his latest tour in Afghanistan, finds himself instead prowling the back country of the Balkans, dodging alien patrols and trying to organize scattered survivors without getting killed. And in the southeastern US, firearms instructor and former Marine Dave Dvorak finds himself at the center of a growing network of resistance--putting his extended family at lethal risk, but what else can you do?On the face of it, Buchevsky's and Dvorak's chances look bleak, as do prospects for the rest of the surviving human race. But it may well be that Shongairi and the Hegemony alike have underestimated the inhabitants of that strange planet called Earth... in David Weber's Out of the Dark.At the Publisher's request, this title is being sold without Digital Rights Management Software (DRM) applied.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: First let me say to my fellow Amazon reviewers, seriously? You're like someone who recommends The Sixth Sense to someone and you start out by saying "So Bruce Willis is a ghost."There is such a thing as a spoiler, and the polite thing to do is not to mention them. It is certainly possible to talk about the book without giving things away.Now my review. I came upon this book through the Warriors Anthology. Of all the twenty-ish stories in that anthology, this short story (which was then expanded into the novel you see here) was my favorite. Yes, the ending was the same.This is the first David Weber book I've read, I get the impression many of the negative reviews are by his long time "fans" so maybe this isn't typically what he writes. I have no preconceived notions so I judged it as is.I really enjoyed it, it is fast paced, the action and military aspects are well described, the level of detail is excellent, and I find the plot and the world he has created wholly unique. Especially given the current geopolitical climate a situation in which we're the insurgency really resonated with me. Also, unlike similar plots such as "Independence Day" where our technology is completely outmatched, I liked that this novel describes a much closer fight where both sides can inflict harm. I also found his explanation for the alien's vulnerability to make sense.The book basically follows the actions of part of an ancient 70,000 some year old alien "hegemony" as they try to subjugate Earth, they're easily able to take out our major cities and military bases, but when they start landing ground troops they become vulnerable and we give it back to them pretty good.As for the ending, I was surprised, I like being surprised, I consider it hard to surprise me. In retrospect there were signs, of course, but it is so out of left field the possibility wasn't even on my radar. It is a little deus ex machina, but I reserve that label for situations where I think the author invented ending to get out of some writer's block, out of convenience. In this case I'm pretty sure David Weber knew his ending before he wrote a word.And yes, the ending is similar to a contemporary fad, but it at least is a very unique application of that subject matter, one I've not heard of or seen before. One might say he was capitalizing on it, as if his motives affect your enjoyment of the book or not. Could he merely have been inspired by it? Maybe thinking along those lines more now because the topic is pretty popular? In any case, his reason for the ending shouldI liked the book so much, I hope he writes a sequel. Seriously, take the battle to the hegemony. Everyone likes the story of an underestimated adversary rising from the ashes like the mythical phoenix to make his antagonist regret ever proviking his ire. In the end thats what you have here. It is very pro-human, and pro-human race, and human civilization, and human exceptionalism. It writes as if we're the best species in the universe out of thousands. That is candy for people prone to patriotism like myself and others. Then it has a very surprising twist. Which, understand, when I first read it, I didn't even know there was a twist in advance, let alone what it was. I hadn't read any reviews, I thought it was straight up man vs. aliens.That is probably the best experience. Even if you read my review, I don't tell you what the twist is, but you know there is one. The best experience is if you know nothing and read it like I did to be fully surprised.On a side note, I also think this would make an excellent movie. As you say, its a fad, and would do well enough at the box office. Plus who doesn't want to see an F-22 shoot down spaceships?
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2010

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: When I picked up this book, I could not wait to finish it.  In fact, I stayed up one whole night to read it.  Was it the theme?  Yes.  Was it the plot?  Kinda.  Was it the detailed explanation of every piece of equipment not currently known to man?  Yes and No.  Was it the character development, such as it was?  I don't know.  Was it the dialogue?  Definitely, yes.  Was it the ability of the writer to show the different points of view?  YES!It seems that I am being critical in my review but bear with me.  Somehow, despite the flaws in the story, I gave it a 4.  Why?  The book was enjoyable from start to finish.  This is what puts it up from a 3 to a 4, for me.  I loved the plot.  I loved the way Mr. Weber was able to bring me into the story.  I felt like I was Fleet Commander Thikair.  At the same time, I was Major Torino.  I was also that poor sap in the Starlander.  Speaking about Starlanders, I hated the detailed description of the machinery.  Frequently, I glanced over those pages.  The descriptions, the ones I actually read, did create a solid setting and contributed to the excellent point of view that Mr. Weber was able to show me.  The character development seemed predictable.  Everyone reacted in a predictable fashion.  The wives in the Dvorak family let their husbands go fight a war with a minimum of protest.  The military types became guerillas.  The vampires...  I wish they had entered the story sooner.  I suspect the author wanted the reader to believe all was lost and just be grateful that humanity would not be wiped off the face of the earth.  If that was his aim, he succeeded but sacrificed an element of the story.  When the book ends, one doesn't know where the vampires came from and why they are mad.  All in all, I loved this book.  I am a fan of David Weber and will continue to be so.I have one question.  This seems to be a book that was set to be the beginning of a series.  Is it?
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2010

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Con un plantemiento ingenuo e infantiloide, el libro se va haciendo más difícil de digerir a medida que avanza la historia. Algunos pasajes son francamente pesados. Lectura a evitar.
I've read this novel twice and it gets better throughout  every time. Great themes, a lot like Eric Frank Russell's works.

Neat premise, harsh realities on human nature and geo-political frailty. Quirky heroes and anti-heroes (good and bad). Some quick (and impressive) plugs for survivialism. Some intelligent aliens, though 'thin' worldbuilding there by Weber's usual standardsSo we have global partisan struggles and despite human frailty some temporary triumphs against the odds. Finally the high tech aliens are too overwhelming and just as adversity grinds humanities last hope down, finally a 'Deus ex Machina' resolution.Good, lightweight, quick read; nothing epic: Very much of the Apocalypse Troll and Dahak standard of writing. Nothing on the Treecat or Harrington level

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Welch eine Überraschung!Also Caniden, oder heissen die vielleicht anders, aber canis heisst doch der Hund, na ja also diese Caniden überfallen aus dem Weltraum die Erde, legen die Zentren von Wirtschaft und Militär in Schutt und Asche und meinen jetzt die Menschheit würde den "Schwanz einziehen", aber Menschen sind ja nicht so. Es regt sich Wiederstand im Untergrund natürlich vor allem in USA, wo jeder doch mindestens eine Waffe besitzt, wie Mr. Weber so richtig weiss. Die Feinde wollen natürlich die Menschheit nicht ganz ausrotten, denn die Menschen werden ja noch als Arbeitssklaven gebraucht und die Ökologie sollte auch in Ordnung bleiben.Da erstellen die Eroberer ein Psychobild der Menschen und machen etwas Neues, sie rauben Kinder und wollen sie "perfekt" erziehen. Da hätte die Menschheit keine Chance mehr. Da kommt Hilfe! !!! und die Erde ist gerettet.Ich verrate nicht welche Hilfe, aber diese Hilfe geht sogar in den Weltraum und wird die Menschheit repräsentieren, welch ein Spass.Hoffentlich gibt es eine Fortsetzung

bookDescription: Humans have been in the stars far longer than Van originally thought, and they’ve been busy.But not every visitor to or from Earth has good intentions, and the Peacemakers are faced with an uncomfortable reality. The Earth is about to meet aliens. Some of the aliens are bringing goods to trade. And among those items—are weapons.When a secret cabal of humans who want to exploit the Earth is revealed, Van has to decide how and where to fight this threat. Along the way, he reveals a secret history that began in the Great War—and ends with mass chaos on his home planet.Van won’t let that happen—at least not without a fight, and to hold back the gears of war, he’s going to need a lot of help. With Torina at his side, the crew faces a decision that will change the future of the stars themselves, and challenge the Guild, the Earth, and the Equal Grasp as the universe gets smaller with each contact between humans and aliens.How can Van manage the clash, save earth, and deliver peace?If he can, what will it cost him?

bookDescription:
The alien forces known as the Lankies are gathering on the solar system’s edge, consolidating their conquest of Mars and setting their sights on Earth. The far-off colony of New Svalbard, cut off from the rest of the galaxy by the Lanky blockade, teeters on the verge of starvation and collapse. The forces of the two Earth alliances have won minor skirmishes but are in danger of losing the war. For battle-weary staff sergeant Andrew Grayson and the ragged forces of the North American Commonwealth, the fight for survival is entering a catastrophic new phase.
Forging an uneasy alliance with their Sino-Russian enemies, the NAC launches a hybrid task force on a long shot: a stealth mission to breach the Lanky blockade and reestablish supply lines with Earth. Plunging into combat against a merciless alien species that outguns, outmaneuvers, and outfights them at every turn, Andrew and his fellow troopers could end up cornered on their home turf, with no way out and no hope for reinforcement. And this time, the struggle for humanity’s future can only end in either victory or annihilation.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Good Book Just wished it moved the story further along
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: At the onset of Angles of Attack the third book in Marko Kloos's Frontline series,  things are not looking good for humanity.  For five years, humanity has been fighting a losing battle of extermination against a seemingly invincible enemy who now stands on the doorstep of Earth about to finish us off.  Our oldest and most populous colony on Mars just fell to the Lankies , all major cities and installations have been cleansed off the planet by nerve gas and the enemy has begun terraforming the planet to meet their own biological needs.  After this defeat, a refugee fleet of the two main powers on Earth, the North American Coalition (NAC) and Sino-Russian Alliance (SRA) arrive in the New Svalbard system where our main character Staff Sergeant Andrew Grayson and a small contingent of NAC soldiers are currently holed up after a successful mutiny which saw Grayson and group of exiled Homeworld Defense soldiers disobey direct orders to seize the resources of New Svalbard from the colonists for use by the NAC.  An alliance of convenience is formed between the NAC and SRA refugee fleets, and although the two sides do not readily trust one another they are willing to integrate their forces towards the greater goal of survival.  However, given the recent influx of soldiers and sailors from the refugee fleet and the fact that the world of New Svalbard is essentially a Hoth-lite planet, the refugee fleet finds itself with two sobering options, starving to death in orbit around their new home or run the risk of running the  blockade around Earth in an attempt reestablish supply lines with Earth.  Fortunately, for our heroes the fleet does possess a state of the art spy vessel with stealth capabilities, the Indianapolis,  that they can use to hopefully break the enemy’s blockade of our solar system.  In the process of doing so they can then discover if Earth is still intact, reestablish contact and then return back to New Svalbard before the colony and fleet around the planet starve to death.  Sounds simple right?  Of course along the way in the novel, things are not always what they seem to be and a constant theme in the book is the inability of humanity and those in power to look beyond self-interest and to actually serve the greater good, even in the face of utter annihilation.All in all, Angles of Attack is a nice addition to the Frontline series and although I found this latest addition  to be the weakest of the three that have been released thus far, I still found it to be a delightfully fun and extremely enjoyable read.  Kloos has an amazing ability to pen taut, frenetic and realistic action sequences that place his readers right in the midst of the action.  Whether it is a highly kinetic firefight or the equally tense action of sneaking through an enemy blockade, Kloos' stories ooze authenticity in a way that many other military space opera novels don't.  Kloos simply does a great job detailing the culture of the militaries he writes about in addition to enumerating the preferred tactics, weapon systems and platforms of said military cultures.  When one picks up Angles of Attack or any other novel in the frontline series , one is presented with a wonderfully realized and fully believable vision of the military in the 22nd Century.In Angles of Attack, the characters in the are well written, even if they do not stray too far from established sci-fi military clichés.  The characterization for most of the characters is not particularly deep, although Kloos through the thoughts/conversations of the main character the author does attempt to deal with the idea of how the individual or even the systems created by individuals (i.e governments, bureaucracies etc) would react to the apocalypse and the the prospect of losing all that one holds dear.  Would a sense of depression or acceptance kick in , or would the animal nature of humanity strike yet again as we lash out of the corner to fight back once again against all odds?  Do we as a species come together in times of crisis or use this as a justification to grow more selfish and ensure our own survival? What if any are the ramifications of such decisions?  Heady questions to be sure, and the author just briefly  touches on them while showing the potential consequences such decisions can have on our ultimate survival.Staff Sergeant Grayson, though weary and battle hardened is given his own level of depth in the novel hidden in his real  motivations why he risks leaving the relative safety of New Svalgrad to accompany the crew of the Indianapolis on their journey back to Earth.  That was a well done touch. Kloos also does a great job portraying the military bureaucracies’ s on both the SRA and NAC sides as soulless machines, faceless and essentially unaccountable machines that grind up and leech all sense of usefulness of those within their ranks, but to what purpose?  To the end of the novel, we see a government and a military that has lost its core reason for being, and it will be interesting to see how this theme is carried on forward in the series.As you can tell, I found much to enjoy about this book.  That being said, my main criticism with the book stems from what I felt was the lack of movement in the main plot of the series.  Towards, the end of the novel, humanity is essentially in the same place as they were at the end of the second novel, Lines of Departure, and our characters though on a different planet with a different difficult decision to make are no closer to saving humanity.  Granted this may have been my own fault as I thought that this was the last book in the series, and was not aware of another upcoming novel in the series, so imagine my surprise/frustration that at the end of the book, we know little more about the Lankies than we did at the end of book two and the story has moved no closer towards either the salvation or extinction of the human race.In short, although a lot happened in the novel, it almost felt at the end like filler, enjoyable, well written filler, but filler nonetheless.  Although interesting questions are posed about the Lankies in this novel, no answers are given and three books in we still don’t know much about the Lankies, their motivations, their society, or even how their ships are made.  While this does serve the story as it makes the enemy mysterious, extremely powerful and frightening, at some point the ant, being humanity, is going to have to learn how to stop the boot of the Lankies from stomping us out of existence.  In fairness to the author however, while he does portray the enemy as semi-invincible, he has provided enough chinks in their armor that one can plausibly see how humanity will prevail. My only hope is that the next novel moves us closer to figuring out how this will be accomplished.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 28, 2015

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I felt almost like there was a missing short story in between the second and third novels in the Frontline series. At the beginning of my last review I mentioned how the Russians, Chinese and Ameriicans were still feuding despite the Lankies attacking all of Earth's colonies.This books jumps right into middle of a joint operation between the Eurasian forces allied with the Americans, fighting their common alien foe. Maybe I've forgotten something.Anyway, the Earth forces out on ice planet Svalbard are soon approaching a time when they and the civilians on the planet will eat their way through all the supplies, and there has been no resupply or communication from Earth for a long time. So, a daring plan is hatched to run the Lankie blockade of the Solar System to make contact with the Earth forces and to see what can be done about relief. Our old comrades, Sergeants Grayson and Fallons, are along for the duration, and we get to live in interesting times along with them.When they arrive, the situation is very strange. Mars has been overrun, and the forces orbiting Earth do not seem to trust the returnees, quarantining the and locking down their communications. Things come to a head when they take Andrew in for interrogation, leaving him in need of rescue by some of his bad companions - another day, another mutiny.With the help of one of Andrew's new Russian friends, Dmitri, they escape the clutches of the powers on Earth (who turn out to be cowards fleeing the solar system) and re-run the blockade in reverse to report on the situation to the remainder of the fleet on Svalbard. After a deal of discussion, it's once more unto the breach for a second voyage back to the home system, where they make contact with the flight school on the Moon, where - Yay! - Andrew's fiancee, Hailey, is a flight instructor.They "borrow" a bunch of fighter spacecraft and their student pilots and make tracks to attack a Lankie mothership which has made it all the way into Earth orbit. Great mayhem ensues.I'm not so certain now that this is going to end as a trilogy. It appears Kloos has left room for a sequel or two. I look forward to finding out.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 22, 2015

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Mira que es difícil mantener la calidad a lo largo de tres libros y que la historia siga atrayendo y no haya altibajos, pero Marko Kloos lo consigue con creces en esta tercera parte. productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Another unputdownable book in the series
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: This series is so good I really struggle to put it down and work. I like that it’s. It all fantasy layers and beam me up Scotty. Sure, we’re talking spaceships and travelling to different star systems, but somehow the narrative feels more rooted in real physics, real military knowledge and real human emotions. Could be I’m a loony but that’s what I think.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: This is the most realistic (warp drives or not) scifi military book I've ever read. My stomach always turned whenever I read sappy Star Trekian books with competent leaders and politicians.The world doesn't work like that and I didn't need to suspend my disbelief at the political chaos in this book. There's no need for Machiavellian plots if sheer incompetence can be attributed to bad decisions.Occam's razor to its finest. Well done.

bookDescription:
Physics doesn’t negotiate. Neither does she.
Twelve years ago, a Polish colony found an alien warship in a debris field. Now every superpower in human space wants what they reverse-engineered.
On the frontier, Polonia Prime is a small, underfunded nation with one unforgivable advantage: hybrid alien drive and weapons technology that can rewrite every fleet doctrine in the Hyades Cluster.
Lieutenant Commander Maria Roszak earned her command through tactical competence, not bloodline or politics. Her destroyer Błyskawica is a relic on the outside, retrofitted inside with forbidden Bubble-drive systems, railgun batteries, and point-defense grids that skate the edge of physics. When a Zenith Caliphate carrier strike group crosses the border to seize Polonia’s secrets, Maria finds herself outnumbered, outgunned—and no longer sure her own side is playing straight.
Every time the enemy finds her faster than they should, suspicion grows. If she’s right about a leak in her own chain of command, exposing it could destroy her career and her ship long before the Caliphate does. To keep her crew alive and her nation independent, Maria must turn debris fields into weapons, doctrine into a disadvantage, and an obsolete destroyer into the sharpest blade in Polonia’s arsenal.
In a battlespace where Newtonian recoil, delta-v budgets, and railgun kinetics decide who lives, one captain’s brain is the only shield her people have left.
For readers who love:
Hard-science military space opera with real-physics combat (Bubble-drive micro-jumps, railguns, missiles, point defense, no magic)
Hard-science military space opera with real-physics combat (Bubble-drive micro-jumps, railguns, missiles, point defense, no magic)
Underdog nations, carrier strike groups, and destroyer-captain tactics under political pressure
Underdog nations, carrier strike groups, and destroyer-captain tactics under political pressure
Competent female officers, gritty tone, and respect for military professionalism
Competent female officers, gritty tone, and respect for military professionalism
Series like The Lost Fleet and The Expanse, where brains matter more than bigger guns
Series like The Lost Fleet and The Expanse, where brains matter more than bigger guns

aPlusContent.title: From the Publisher
aPlusContent.rawText:
From the Publisher
THE CUTTING EDGE OF INTERSTELLAR WARFARE 
The destroyer Błyskawica represents Polonia Prime's technological triumph, combining human engineering with reverse-engineered alien technology. Captain Maria Roszak commands this formidable vessel through the contested regions of the Hyades Cluster, where her tactical brilliance will be tested against forces that threaten humanity's fragile peace. 
FORGED IN THE CRUCIBLE OF BATTLE 
The Neo-Russian battlecruiser Volkov unleashes devastating firepower against Caliphate forces. These rugged vessels emphasize durability and overwhelming force projection, representing the iron will of a civilization determined to protect its hard-won territory in the Hyades Cluster through superior firepower and tactical resolve. 
MASTERY OF SPACE AND TIME 
Witness the revolutionary bubble drive in action as a Polonia Prime vessel prepares for faster-than-light travel. This alien-derived technology creates a quantum displacement field that allows ships to traverse vast interstellar distances in moments. While commercial versions enable trade throughout the Hyades Cluster, military-grade systems grant Polonia Prime's navy unprecedented tactical advantage in combat situations. 
THE HEART OF POWER THAT DRIVES THE STARS 
The engineering section houses Polonia Prime's revolutionary bubble drive technology, reverse-engineered from alien discoveries. This advanced propulsion system allows rapid tactical jumps between star systems, giving Polonia Prime's vessels unprecedented strategic advantage in both military operations and interstellar trade. 
ELITE FORCES ON THE FRONTLINES OF HUMANITY'S DEFENSE 
Polonia Prime's marine contingents represent the cutting edge of military training and equipment. These elite troops specialize in ship-to-ship boarding actions, planetary landings, and station security operations, bringing human determination and tactical flexibility to the most dangerous environments in the Hyades Cluster.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Premise is good.  Not really very military, more space opera with out a lot of science.  At first it seemed the Polish colony had an exclusive on the bubble drive, then it didn't.  A scene where the Polish Captain was under orders of a Anglo Commander, and the Anglo insistence in control of the op, then he abandons the Polish Marines; no follow up on what happens to him.  A scene where the Caliphate cruisers are trailing their coats, everybody going to get them, then boom, the Polish ship ordered away from the action.  No followup on the cruiser threat.  Marine Private, Navel ensign/JG romance winked at by all.  Huh?  The author really, really needed a good editor and some critical friends.  This could be good world building, but right now it is a series of sketches that want fleshing out to make a story, and make a series.  I probably won't buy the next books in the series.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A space opera, mostly of the old school
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I found the quality of writing mostly very good. The story itself seems very old-school. The setting is the nearby Hyades star cluster, a young group of stars, likely to possess no living planets. The choice of the Theta stars is particularly odd, as these are mostly massive stars, short-lived and highly energetic, including one already evolved into or perhaps past it's helium flash. But most of the story seems to be on stations. And that's one of the oddities, as these station locations are very ambiguous. Some of that may be due to the "bubble drive" a jump drive of unclear capabilities, short, long, maybe gravity sensitive, maybe not...The heroine seems very young, but immensely capable (I say apparently, but she is chronologically early middle age). Most of her crew we meet are ensigns and privates. So, a bit of a mix of a YA story and ??? The heroine's ship is an old destroyer with some alien tech modes. Not really clear what is involved, but it does seem to be a bit of a super ship with a super tactician commanding. A bit hard to tell what pushes it in normal space, maybe some anti-inertia, but only because it seems, in a push, it can make quick reverses...  The plot is mostly a series of battles. Outside the somewhat sketchy battle scenes,  our youngish captain seems to be right in the middle of even the highest level meetings. Odd...Mostly, I found the writing above average, and some excellent. The Sci-Fi seemed to be bits and pieces, patched with no real since of realism, more like a movie.A pretty good read, but I don't think I'll go after the sequel.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: The Lightning War: Rising Storm is a gripping military sci-fi novel blending high-stakes space combat, political intrigue, and compelling characters. Fans of tactical warfare and rich world-building will find it a thrilling and satisfying read.

I enjoy reading about strong, fearless, intelligent women. Captain Maria Roszak comes across as just that as she navigates one difficulty after another in her role as commander of the Blyskawika. Here we see something unusual, and for fans of sci-fi, there is plenty to get your head around. So relevant to the times we are experiencing, cyber warfare is as devastating as the brains behind the politics, but the battle is always about power and greed. I enjoyed the story, though I felt at times there was unfinished business afoot: maybe to be picked up in the sequel.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Gripping story of politics and battles in space
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Superb writing sweeps the reader through Polonia Prime’s battle for survival against larger neighbouring powers in the human colonies of the Hyades Cluster. We avidly follow Maria Roszak, Executive Officer on board the destroyer Blyskawica, as her innovative strategies and tactical acumen make brilliant use of the engineering and IT insight of the bridge crew. Other characters are vividly drawn and the friendly camaraderie and honed teamwork are an intrinsic part of the Blyskawica’s success. I would have appreciated more insight into what it feels like to live on a ship in space and also a better impression of travelling in space. The author gives little impression of distances and speeds, whether within systems or between stars. It does not really matter as I was gripped by the twists and turns of the story and concerns of the characters. I look forward to reading more of their adventures.

bookDescription: In New York Times-bestselling science fiction epic Out of the Dark, Earth beat back an alien invasion. Now we've got to make sure they don't come back, in Into the Light.The Shongairi conquered Earth. In mere minutes, half the human race died, and our cities lay in shattered ruins.But the Shongairi didn’t expect the survivors’ tenacity. And, crucially, they didn’t know that Earth harbored two species of intelligent, tool-using bipeds. One of them was us. The other, long-lived and lethal, was hiding in the mountains of eastern Europe, the subject of fantasy and legend. When they emerged and made alliance with humankind, the invading aliens didn’t stand a chance.Now Earth is once again ours. Aided by the advanced tech the aliens left behind, we’re rebuilding as fast as we can.Meanwhile, a select few of our blood-drinking immortals are on their way to the Shongairi homeworld, having commandeered one of the alien starships...the planet-busting kind.At the Publisher's request, this title is being sold without Digital Rights Management Software (DRM) applied.
